TopicTitle: GOCU satellite piece burned over Texas

Articles.Content: Anyone else have any sightings? I assume it was a piece because it coincided with the satellite's relative position and burned for a while, about a quarter of the sky.

My dad weared a helmet the entire day.

Dad humor.

My dad weared a helmet the entire day.

Dad humor.

Meh, I stayed inside in the basement the whole day, wearing a helmet. After that, I followed up with a vigil in memoriam of the satellite, followed by a six gun salute of airsoft guns.

Don't ask.

Anyone else have any sightings? I assume it was a piece because it coincided with the satellite's relative position and burned for a while, about a quarter of the sky.

According to a BBC article from about 45 minutes ago, initial estimates are that any debris came down along a line stretching through eastern Asia and the western Pacific to Antarctica. While Texas is indeed big, none of those places are in Texas.

Yeah, now that I look at it, it wasn't the same trajectory as the satellite. Even though it was the appropriate time period, the object I saw was travelling more northeast. Just a run of the mill meteor I guess. It burned bright blue, with a small explosion towards the end.

I may still claim it as satellite debris though in retellings of the story. Life needs little embellishments.
So then why introducing a disinformation on the internets?

So then why introducing a disinformation on the internets?

There's disinformation on teh interwebz?

There's disinformation on teh interwebz?

Well this is how they start. As memes. Google will pick it up, people will search for it, Google will offer it in the search field... Memes. *aliens*
